reviewText:
A horrifying examination of human psychological weakness, Clicker Heroes is more disturbingly respectable than clear satire such as Progress Quest for being a fully realized and quite serious effort of game design, but it is not to be played—it is to be hooked up to a computer in a museum where children can go and watch it work (from behind the safety of a thick glass shield) so that they might return home motivated by recurring nightmares which serve to forever remind them of the ease with which a person can be seduced into wasting their life.

If we ever manage to build utopia, the cornerstone of its educational program will be a forced hour-long session of Clicker Heroes that ends with students being informed that their genetic sequence has been inextricably attached to their game profile and that they will be unceremoniously exiled to labor camps on the Moon if they should ever demonstrate the feeble-mindedness necessary to return and play for a second time.

When the human race is finally enslaved by its mechanical progeny and harvested within illusory biofarm prison-paradises, our digital overlords will have no need of an elaborate computer simulation to placate our minds; for that they will have Clicker Heroes.

It is a masterpiece of modern art and social engineering, one of the crowning accomplishments of all mankind.  Now get the hell away from it.

reviewText:
I'm making this review a week into the game.

I have 62 hours played. (168 hours in a week, 37% of the week)

Day 1) I saw a free game/indie game, my 2 weaknesses. I didn't stop playing the entire day.

Day 2) I changed my steam name and icon to the beloved Treebeast.

Day 3) I spread the Clicker Heroes plague to all my friends.

Day 4) No one can stop.

Day 5) We are in Skype calls, silent, except for the sounds of furious clicking.

Day 6) I quit my job.

Day 7) I blink for the first time in 2 days. Remarkable. I realize now how serious this has gotten. I look around me. Dirty        clothes, Doritos bags, dog ♥♥♥♥, a ruined home, Clicker Heroes. I ignore my surroundings and persevere onward.

10/10   Join the plague.

reviewText:
It's an addiction. I am not joking. You don't want to be addicted to this. There are expansive fantasy worlds to explore, intriguing mysteries, puzzles to solve, and stories to be told. And here I am, instead of any of those other games that actually have that, I'm just... clicking a monster.

This is half-joking, but also containing my honest opinion. I just don't like what these type of games make you do. Get addicted to some other game. Thank you for reading this humble little review.

Back then, most clicker games had a better idea when to stop, like Candy Box, A Dark Room, & Space Lich Omega. They all have a good story, there is actual exploration, ASCII art, and they don't break your mouse.

reviewText:
Please help me.
I got this game somewhere between two days and two years ago. Hard to tell. Most of my time has been spent playing it. My arm hurts from clicking, there's a feral creature shrieking persistently in my skull, and my mouse seems to have taken to sobbing silently when I get to a boss level. I'm only writing this to give myself a brief reprieve from the game. Even now it's still open, whispering softly and seductively to me, bending me slowly backwards with its long, icy fingers. This game is my drug, and I can't ♥♥♥♥ing stop clicking. It has me trapped, helpless, teaching me hundreds of new ways to be addicted to something. Clicker Heroes is the dark, divine deity to which cocaine and heroin pray. If you find this, contact los federales, or mi madre, I'm frightened and afraid of what Clicker Heroes might do to me.

8/8

reviewText:
It's the most repetitive, nonsensical, stupidly simple game ever.

And I love it.

It's not for everyone. This game will probably only appeal to the 'clicker games' type people, or people like me who just like to see progress without doing anything.

Pros:

-After awhile, you are able to just sit and wait while you rack up gold to level up your heroes. (Actually doing this right now as I write this review)

-A few different skills that you're able to apply with cooldown, like 30sec of autoclicking

-You can literally play this game while you do something else more important, like playing other games

-Damage. Lots of it. Bajillions damage within seconds.

-It's free. The only people who will complain are just not into these types of games and should know not to play it in the first place.

Cons:

-Obviously repetitive

-Lacks more variety, which this is a young (EDIT: Young on Steam) game so I'm sure more stuff will be added

reviewText:
I can't think of a review, so here's a cinnamon roll recipe:

Ingredients

For the Dough:
1 cup whole milk
one 1/4-ounce packet active dry yeast (2 1/2 teaspoons)
1/4 cup plus 1/4 teaspoon granulated sugar
4 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted, plus more for the bowl
1 large egg yolk
1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla extract
2 3/4 cups all-purpose flour, plus more if needed
3/4 teaspoon salt
1/2 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg
For the Filling:
All-purpose flour, for dusting
12 tablespoons unsalted butter, softened, plus more for the pan
1/2 cup granulated sugar
3 tablespoons ground cinnamon
For the Glaze:
2 cups confectioners' sugar
1/3 cup heavy cream
4 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted

Directions

Make the dough: Warm the milk in a medium saucepan over low heat until it reaches about 100. Remove from the heat and sprinkle in the yeast and 1/4 teaspoon sugar (don't stir). Set aside until foamy, 5 minutes. Whisk in the melted butter, egg yolk and vanilla.

Whisk the flour, the remaining 1/4 cup sugar, the salt and nutmeg in the bowl of a stand mixer. Make a well in the center and pour in the yeast mixture. Mix on low speed with the dough hook until thick and slightly sticky. Knead on medium speed until the dough gathers around the hook, 6 minutes. (Add up to 2 more tablespoons flour if necessary.)

Remove the dough and shape into a ball. Butter the mixer bowl and return the dough to the bowl, turning to coat with butter. Cover with plastic wrap and let rise until doubled, 1 hour 15 minutes.

Roll out the dough, fill and cut into buns (see instructions below). Butter a 9-by-13-inch baking pan; place the buns cut-side down in the pan, leaving space between each. Cover with plastic wrap and let rise until doubled, 40 minutes. Preheat the oven to 325.

Bake the buns until golden brown, about 35 minutes. Cool in the pan 15 minutes. Meanwhile, make the glaze: Sift the confectioners' sugar into a bowl, then whisk in the cream and melted butter. Transfer the buns to a rack and spoon the glaze on top while still warm.

How to Form Cinnamon Buns

1. On a lightly floured surface, roll the dough into a 12-by-14-inch rectangle with the longer side facing you.

2. Spread with the softened butter, leaving a 1/2-inch border on the far long edge. Mix the sugar and cinnamon; sprinkle over the butter.

3. Brush the unbuttered far edge with water. Roll the dough away from you into a tight cylinder and press on the long edge to seal.

4. Cut the cylinder with a sharp knife to make 6 equal-size buns.

reviewText:
This review does not take into consideration any changes since August 2015.
I cannot recommend this title, and here's why:

There's mainly 2 ways to play the game, actively or passively. Pursuing the game actively highly involves clicking the enemy target for as long as your fingers, toes, and other creative means allow you to go on. Do take note, that even if you decided on taking the active route because it may seem like you'll progress faster in the short future, in the long run, the difference isn't as huge as one might think.

Passive gameplay involves opening the game, leaving a few tweaks on upgrades and then closing the game again. The main aspect of this gameplay is what it does while the game is shut down, as it also fights passively for you once you get your very first few upgrades.

For both gameplay types there's a later game strategy, as you decide between which skills you use and which special supportive powers called Ancients you invest in (by spending hero souls, the currency of the game). These can highly change the speed of your progression throughout the game. However, sooner or later you'll hit a wall where your damage is simply no longer enough for progressing with your current upgrades. This will force you to start the game countless times back at stage 1 in order to earn more hero souls for upgrades. So, you'll have to gear yourself with remarkable amounts of patience (if you can call it that) if you plan on getting anywhere in this game, as it won't change an inch beyond selecting upgrades.

My main objective when I started the game was to get its achievements, which I at first thought would've been a breeze considering the lack of any requirements beyond clicking. It's even capable of idling and playing itself while you're gone. How hard can it be? The plan was to only spend small amounts of time on the game, which didn't happen, as the game also rewards you for actively playing. Hoping to rush through the game quicker for the achievements, I continued.

The trap in all of this is for people who wish to 100% it, for this is no easy task due to it being the same thing for something which feels and looks like... an eternity.

Would I recommend people to play this game? No, I really can't say that there's anything to come here for, other than a quick fix of satisfaction for a few minutes for the active player, just to realise later that you'll be that bit more disappointed that you even spent your time on it in the first place. And as a passive player, you're in for a long wait consisting of tiny upgrading and no variation.

Through all this, I've learnt that clicker games don't work for me, even though I had thought they might've at first! At least not when it's executed in the way that Clicker Heroes had. Perhaps I would've been better prepared for it in the beginning had it been called Passive Heroes. And maybe by removing the clicking feature alltogether, and making it a passive waiting game would've made the experience very different.

tldr;
It gets tedius very, very fast and you should probably be spending your gaming time elsewhere. I wouldn't want to recommend such an experience to anyone. It feels like a human experiment. The princess is in another castle~

Overall, if you insist and MUST play it, I would recommend the passive route a lot more and think of the game as passive heroes instead of clicker heroes, as the reward vs investment in active gameplay is just not there.

reviewText:
In my Opinion, Clicker Heroes is the best idle game out there and I have played alot of them. The game is very easy to understand, yet, there's deep strategy involved. You click to deal damage, you buy heroes (and upgrades) to deal damage over time and you buy (and level up) ancients to improve your damage, your gold gains or even reduce the amount of monsters you have to kill to progress.

There are tons of ways you can play the game, just by the way you build your ancients. You can focus on having your skills last for a long time, you can focus on dealing as much damage over time as possible without clicking or you can make it so your clicks are extremely strong. Of course, with a lot of time and effort, you can buy and level up any ancients, but the amount of time it takes to get there depends on how good your strategy is.

Also, they are always adding new content to the game and improving it, so if you ever get bored, come back 3-6 months later and you will have new heroes, ancients and/ or features that will have been implemented!

PROs:

-It's free.
-It's fun.
-It's easy to play.
-The game is being updated every few months.
-You can leave the game closed and you keep progressing.
-You can play this game while waiting for multiplayer games to start or when you have 5 minutes of free-time at work.
-The achievements are great and there are many to unlock (most of them are also Steam Achievements).
-The replayability of this game is endless...
-The monsters and backgrounds are really cool.

CONs:

-There's only 1 music in the game.
-It does get repetitive, but starting over or waiting for updates usually does the trick.

I totally suggest ANYONE try out this game. It's really great and it's free. Also, you can obtain rubies while playing (so no, it's not pay-to-win). Also, beware that this game is tremendously addicting! Do yourself a favor and download it, enjoy the game. :)

reviewText:
Clicker Heroes


Another game people will either love (for unknown reasons) or simply disregard due to its nature.


The game in a nutshell

You click on static monsters and each click will deal damage. When the monster dies it drops gold. You accumulate gold and purchase upgrades which makes your clicking stronger. Monsters only vary in visual display and have no abilities or resists. Only an ever increasing pool of health which is depenant on the zone level. Killing 10 monsters in a zone level will open up the next zone level. Every 10 zone levels there are Bosses. Special monsters with much more health which only give you a timewindow of 30 seconds to beat before they restet to full health and the time window starts anew. You must kill these in order to progress and can see them as benchmarks" to check if you are ready or not.

Apart from active play the game will simulate your progress (measured by your DPS
date:
not clicking damage) even if you are offline tho you cannot progress passively (yet). Entering the next zone is an active thing but if you are missing out on gold to purchase that next upgrade you can let it run in offline mode for an hour or two and continue from there.


going deeper

Clicking is only your first layer tho. You quickly open up new heroes which provide you with your second layer of gameplay. DPS aka Damage Per Second. These heroes deal damage over time on their own. Even if you stop clicking damage will continue to pour in. So DPS is kind of like a passive buff for your game. Apart from buying heroes to become active (first purchase to level 1) you can continue leveling them up to make their DPS stronger in turn enhancing your killing power of the monsters on the screen.

In addition each hero has a set of abilities which unlock at certain levels (10
voteText:
75 and 100) providing better capabilities or ACTIVE ABILITIES


it becomes more then mindless clicking

There are 9 active abilities you can trigger at any point. Each one has an effect duration (usually 30 seconds) and a cool-down preventing you from spamming them. Effects range from more click damage to more gold per kill to support buffs and even a permanent damage buff. Unlocking these abilities and timing their use will become a key part of defeating higher level Bosses


it just doesnt stop

There will be a point where you ll run into a "wall". Monsters will become so powerfull that it takes a long time to kill them and bosses will eventually become so mighty that you will be unable to beat them even if you use all your active abilities. This is the point where you use the "Ascension" feature for the first time.

At first it doesnt sound like anything anybody in his right mind would do. "Creates a new universe
helpfulPercent:
much like the current one. This will restart your game and you will receive XXX Hero Souls".

Wait.....It just resets my game to level one....all gold and hero levels are gone and I simply start over? LAME!!!!!!

But wait....whats these hero souls then?


Hero Souls....the meta game

Hero Souls are kind of a permanent currency coming through an ascension. Each one you have banked (read....showing in your display) will increase your damage by 10%. Its accumulative so if you have 5 your whole damage will increase by 50%. With 10 of these babies you ll DOUBLE your damage. So even tho you have to go through all the levels you beat beforehand a second time.....THIS time will be far easier and much quicker to get to the point where you grinded to a stop before and continue past that point.

And thats not all. As a permanent currency they open up the market for a special sort of heroes. The Ancients.


Ancient Heroes....the game turns tactical

What makes these heroes special is that they also....just like Hero Souls transfer through an ascension and you gonna keep them. There is a whole list of them and each one buffs your game in a special way. Purchasing them costs hero souls. Leveling them up costs hero souls and you ll need to start thinking about what will give you the most bang for your buck (read....do you keep the HS banked or do you invest them?)

You ll soon realize that many ancients support each other so getting the "right mix" of ancients can massively increase your efficiency at going through the treadmill (ascend and go through all those levels again).


The truth comes out...whats it all about

Now the game shows its true color. With all these features unlocked you are ready for the neverending(!) "management and improvement of resources" to push further on a new try which makes so many other genres successfull.

4x
RTS
RPGs
ARPGs
Economy Simulations

If you enjoy any of these genres chances are you ll LOVE clicker heroes. Its free to play so what do you have to lose?



Me...I find myself booting it up almost every day and even tho I ascended more then a hundred times already it doesnt really get old. The asciension is more like a "test run" by now to see if you made the correct choices on spending your hero souls and which ancients to get and level. Its this "game within game" which makes me come back....certainly not the clicking. Theres some form of "grinding" to get enough HS but many games have this so not really a problem.

Its a most simple game and the fact that its so addictive is baffling in itself.

For myself I can say that its been a great way to "waste" my freetime so far. I dont regret picking it up :)"

reviewText:
Essential steps to retaining your mouse:

1. Get a mouse with a scroll wheel
1. Google and install 'Auto Hot Key' (2.7MB)
2. Right click on desktop and select New > AutoHotKey script
3. Add:
WheelUp::Click left
WheelDown::Click left
to the bottom of the text document, and save it to wherever
4. Double click it to run it (right click it in the taskbar to disable it again)
5. Throw yourself into the infinite number grinder
6. Feel superior because you've 'cheated' the game, start scrolling
7. Slowly realise the game actually just cheated you because the game doesn't give a ♥♥♥♥ if you're clicking faster or more comfortably than usual you're neck deep in this infinite number grinder its got your throat your life is over*

*but your mouse is ok

reviewText: DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME!\nSeriously, it's a free-to-play version of Cookie Clicker, except with In-Game Purchases, so you can get further in its never-ending battles.  There's no real strategy, no real purpose, it's just clicking mindlessly and spending 'rewards' to get things to click for you faster.  I put probably 100+ hours into this (most of the time in the background), restarted it four times, was doing 22 Decillion damage per second, and was still spending minutes as it beat each monster. There is seriously no redeeming value in this game, and it is insidiously addictive.  Stay far away. You've been warned.

reviewText:
Clicker Heroes Version 0.17d review published 2015/05/16 22:38

Clicker Heroes... A game about clicking and clicking even more to be able to get upgrades so when you click your clicking is better, you do more damage with your clicks as you have to kill enemies and bosses to get to the next stage.
But you don't need to click to move through the levels, you can buy heroes for coins that are dropped in-game these heroes damages the enemies for you. Although by clicking it does go faster to kill the enemy. Once the heroes are bought you can start leveling the heroes and buy upgrades to them or save up coins to purchase a new hero. You can do all that by just using your mouse and then you just point and click. Really simple.

There isn't a huge amount of different monsters but there isn't a too small of an amount of monsters either so you won't see the same enemy over and over again after each other.
You can see your stats and achievements in-game, yes this game has achievements, it has around 60 achievements at the moment. A bunch of levels and heroes, an endless game! I have no idea if It's endless but i assume it is :P

I'd like to point out that it is not Pay 2 Win which is good! But obviously there is stuff to buy for real money but it's not necessary but It's probably easier to progress if you pay. But still not necessary.
Graphics are good.
Gameplay is easy. Not much to do other than clicking and watching.
It has sound effects and in-game music which isn't disturbing, you can easily turn it on or off if you'd like by clicking. But i did wish that they would allow you to lower the Audio in the options instead of either turning it completely off or on, but luckily I found out that you can go to your sound mixer thingy and turn it down a bit there if you'd like.
Options are simple like i said about the audio, wish they made it so you could change the volume in-game. They even have a options to make the monsters tiny, in case you lag it'll help reduce the lag for you :)

If you want to try it you definitely should, doesn't take long at all to install and if you ever get tired of clicking you can keep the game running in the background but make sure you've purchased a hero that can keep slaying monsters for you while you're letting someone massage your clicking finger. I use the index finger for clicking but who knows you may use your thumb.

Anyway good fun game just don't get stuck because it is pretty pointless. But it's a great way to kill time if you're maybe waiting for something or someone.
I might have missed a few things to say about the game but I'm no professional review writer. So if you're going to hate on my review go ahead :) But any tip for future reviews would be helpful.

Another word for this game is:  Money

EDIT: 2015-05-18: This is just a review about this game with my own opinions, if you're looking for a guide i recommend: Beginner's Guide to Clicker Heroes by [DFC]Richard

reviewText:
This is ridiculous. Any clicker game is ridiculous. All you do is slay a monster, buy heroes to slay more for you; they are able to slay more powerful ones, thus you gather more gold and buy more powerful heroes to slay more powerful mosters for more gold and... until it is not possible for you to mathematically achieve the next level. Then you ascend, restart all your progress with some permanent buffs and repeat the whole process. All of this is accompanied by a repetetive, yet delusionaly heroic music. It is brainwashing! There seems to be no end to this! It is a neverending cycle.

There are fragments of a story and humorous anecdotes given within hero or power descriptions, but aside from giving you a brief smile, they are completely irrelevent. Clicker Heroes manages to keep its entitled promise: a complete, yet addictive waste of time and a vain, meaningless sense of achievement for each level you pass. A game could not be more superficial; and more addictive, and relaxing! That's why it is ridiculous.

...Click, click, click, upgrade, click, click, new hero, click, click, upgrade, click, click, new level...

Make a favor to yourself. Don't play this game. Don't waste your time. Go home, have sometime with your friends, family and significant other. Whatever. Leave here before this meaningless game drives you to buy a new mouse and turns you into an embodiment of modern consumption. I know it's tempting, yet you gotta have better things to do! No? Maybe you'd like to try the game for an hour or so? Just an hour? Don't be naive! Don't install this! Please! Oh, crap... I tried. Have fun with your mousekiller, you sad, sad little soul.

Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
6-8?/10 - Why did I start playing this game... and why can't I stop?

I haven't felt this guilty about a decision since sneaking cigarettes after telling everyone I successfully quit. I'm not impressed with this game; I just find myself sadly addicted to it. With over 1,000 games in my inventory you'd think I'd play something amazing. No. I'd rather perpetually click the same spot on the screen or just stare at the game for hours without any interaction.

If you have ever downloaded SETI to scan for aliens it's much like that. You are constantly running the program, working towards a goal that can never really be achieved. You do make enough progress to keep things interesting and wanting to come back for more.

What's the premise? You constantly train your heroes to be more powerful, each level the monsters get more difficult and this cycle never ends. After 18 hours I have a few TRILLION dps, but I'm only a quarter the way to finishing off the next boss.

Bored? Don't want to play a good game? Need another bad habit? Play this!

It's FREE; so check it out... but be warned! I'm uninstalling now for good...

reviewText: I've been actively playing this non-stop since v0.11 back in September 13, 2014 and equally as crazy, I have been streaming my progression on twitch for the same amount of days.\n\nCalling this game addicting" is an understatement. It will truly test your patience and bring out the OCD in everyone. I highly recommend this game to anyone who's looking for a "side/idle-game" to play while you're searching for a match or just simply watching some shows. But be forewarned
date:
there is nothing "idle" about this game as the developers would lead you to believe. ;)

ClickerHeroes is all about incremental progression. You start off ridiculously slow but the time and effort put into it will surely be rewarding (on a personal level).

For those who's just starting out
recommended:

reviewText: If you want to improve at maths, play this game. It's more about calculation to figure out the best DPS and fastest way to gain hero souls" than it is about clicking.\n\nThe way it works
date: you get a whole bunch of heroes. The first one improves your click damage
recommended: and all other heroes do DPS
hoursPlayed: which is an acronym that stands for Damage Per Second. Literally
voteText: they do damage automatically and you don't need to do anything for it. You increase their level to make them do more damage using gold dropped by monsters you kill. At certain levels
helpfulPercent: a new skill unlocks which gives effects ranging from increasing that hero's damage by 100%
votesHelpful: or increasing overall DPS by all your heroes by 25%
votesTotal: increasing your click damage by a certain percentage of your heroes' total DPS (which is actually the brunt of your click damage)
votesFunny: etc. Some of them teach a skill. There are nine skills in the game. For example
commentsCount: Clickstorm is a skill that automatically does 10 clicks per second for 30 seconds
column16: with a 10 minutes cooldown. Proper use of skills is important to kill monsters faster. Especially because...\n\nThere are bosses. You have 30 seconds to kill them. If you don't kill them in time
column17: you can't progress to the next stage. Every stage consists of ten monsters
column18: and there is a boss every five stages
column19: on multiples of five. By stage 100 and above
column20: bosses have a chance to be "Primal"
column21: which is a special version of the boss that drops "hero souls". Every boss from stages in multiples of ten starting from stage 100 (100
column24: etc) give a "gild" to a random hero from your list. At stage 100
column25: you also unlock ancients.\n\nHero souls is a special "currency" that does two things. First
column26: it increases your base DPS (what you have when you start the game) by 10% for each hero soul you have. It doesn't show in your DPS that is shown in your total current DPS shown in the hero tab
column27: but it definitely affects it. Having hero souls is important to improve your damage and general progression
column28: or else your DPS is too slow. However
column29: they also serve as currency to unlock ancients.\n\nAncients are special "characters" that do various passive bonuses. There are a bit over 20 of them
column30: and four are selected randomly for you to pick one from. It can be rerolled if you don't want them
column31: but that costs hero souls. Anyway
column32: ancients effects include increasing all your DPS by a certain amount but only when you are idle (i.e. not clicking or using skills for 60 seconds)
column33: increasing the amount of time you get to fight a boss
column35: getting a LOT more gold from random treasure chests
column36: etc. Ancients are absolutely key to progressing in the game
column37: so you need to find a good balance between keeping enough hero souls on yourself to keep a good DPS bonus
column38: while still improving your ancients that will benefit you more than the hero souls' DPS you lose for improving said ancients. It can get very technical on a mathematical level.\n\nGilds are a type of bonus awarded to your heroes. They're assigned to a random hero when you get them from defeating a boss that is a  multiple of 10 starting from stage 100
column39: but it is later possible to move them to other heroes for a cost (in hero souls). A gild improves that hero's damage by 50%
column40: and gilds are cumulative. For instance
column41: having five gilds on a hero increases its damage by 250%. You definitely want those on heroes that gain a lot of "attack bonus" skills on themselves (such as Masked Samurai) rather than on heroes that have other effects that don't involve having a lot of DPS (such as Alexa which mostly improves click and critical damage
column42: Midas which mostly improves gold drops
column44: "Ascension" is the other important mechanic to explain. Once you get the skill "ASCENSION" from the hero named Amenhotep
column45: you can learn the skill to do an ascension
column46: which brings you down to the first stage and you lose all your money and your heroes lose all their skills. In exchange for "starting over"
column47: you gain a certain amount of hero souls based on a few things.\n\nHero souls gained from killing a Primal boss are only truly awarded after ascending. Also
column48: each 2000 cumulative hero levels you had before ascension give an additional hero soul upon ascension. When you ascend
column49: you keep your gilds and ancients. With the hero souls you gain
column50: you are able to progress faster than the previous time
column51: and you can get overall further and faster. A lot of the joy in the game is the way you get a little bit further than the last time you ascended
column52: each time you get there.\n\nThere's a bit more to the game
column53: but this is most of the important stuff that you need to know. Another thing of note which
column55: is not explained by the game
column57: a hero gains four times the amount of DPS as normal
column60: ten times that amount at level 1000 (and 2000 and 3000). It's important to note because once you get to a certain point and the next hero (Dread Knight) is just faaaaaar too expensive
column61: you want to go back to your first hero and level him up to 1000 which becomes the new best thing
column62: rather than keep increasing the last available hero (Frostleaf) who gains rather minimal DPS. You'll need to ascend many many times before you can even dream of getting Dread Knight
column63: so get those early heroes to level 1000 which is the new meta at that point.\n\nSince a lot of the progression is done through DPS
column65: it's an easy game to play which you can leave running in the background while you do other things and that you can check on once in a while. One thing of note is that when the game is closed
column66: your heroes still are gaining gold from monsters they kill. It's like the game keeps playing itself even when it's closed
column67: although they won't progress to the next level/set of enemies or go past bosses and such. Only gold from monsters of the current highest stage you're at is considered. Since this is such a relaxing game to play
column68: which you don't need to pay a whole lot of attention to most of the time
column69: I recommend it to whoever isn't afraid of doing some maths to maximize their experience with the game. Or following a guide
column71: it is a very known fact that you can use "autoclicker" programs with this game. I personally don't because it's not something I feel is natural to the game's intent and purposes
column72: but it's something you can do
column73: which a lot of people do. When playing without
column74: most of the damage come from DPS and you don't need to click and/or can click only for important stuff such as bosses when you need the extra damage (and/or when using all your skills together for burst damage). Of course having such a program running nonstop will be a large part of your damage compared to someone playing without
column75: especially with relevant ancients that complement that

reviewText:
what can be said about this game beside... click... click... click... click...   I suspect this game was created by a mouse maker villain, with a handle bar mustache, monocle, top hat and cane....  He and the other evil board members got together and thought up an evil plot to fleece money from PC gamers.

The idea they came up with that fateful day was Clickr Heroes..   Oh it's true, it's dang true.. you'll click.. and click.. and click.. and continue to click until your right mouse button stops working...  Stop playing.... gah never... you have yet to unlock that next hero, without him all is lost, the universe will be lost...

You'll wonder why you decided to play this game.... wait a minute, I need to click this fish,,, super he gave me a ruby..

Fun, simplistic, and clicky, this game will eat away hours of your time, you'll want to stop playing but for some strange mystical reason you'll continue to come back..  It'll begin to take over your life.. wake up in the middle of the night... let me just spend this gold real quick...  before work... let me spend this gold...  after work...... more gold... before sleep.... GOLD.....

Ahh, just do it.. allow yourself to submit to the power of Clickr Heroes.... oh yeah.. never buy the gold with your rubies....

reviewText: 518.1 hours on record, but most of that is just letting it sit idle to farm as I did other things like sleep or played better games. A friend removed me because I told him that I was going to play a game with him and after 5 minutes it still said 'In Game; Clicker Heroes' and he thought I was ignoring him. I originally got it for my kid so he had somethign easy to play but I ended up taking it over. There is nothing really fun about this game; you just stare mindlessly at the screen constantly clicking your mouse. The game is designed to take advantage of people's patience and addictive natures. My son accidently deleting my save file after 500 hours was probably one of the best things that's ever happened to me. 1/5

reviewText:
I cannot recommend this game to anyone. Why, you may ask? Simply because of the fact that its purely meant to consume your time.

You kill mosters by clicking or idling and use the gold which they drop to improve your character and buy heroes and imrpove those.
So far for that. You do that until you reach lvl 130-140 where you simply never ever will pass the bosses. (too low dmg)
Then, you restart the game. You gain Hero Souls, which give you dmg boosts if you keep them or can be used to buy other extras.

Thats it. You play the game util you can't proceed any further, then you resett, gain hero souls, play until you [...]
As always, there is the shortcut of paying. You can pay to improve your heroes, you can pay for hero souls, you can pay for relics, you can pay for basicly anything you want.

So... either play this for hundreds / thousands of hours (because there is no end" unless you count 100% achievements as finishing a game) or you ... quit halfway through. Optional

reviewText: This game holds the award the most i have played a single game in a one week span. Dont ask me how such a simple and pretty stupid game idea could be so utterly addicting, because even i myself have no idea. When i first downloaded this game i figured it would keep me occupied for a few hours of a boring summer day. little did i know that i would be strung out a week later with an extremely sore right hand from vigorous clicking for hours on end. It was during  a late night trip to the lid, 1 week and 50 or so ascensions later, that i realized how idiotic it was for me to put so much time into an offline, frankly stupid game. Out of impulse i deleted this game from my steam library and destroyed the file saves i had with it. I feel like a new man. Somewhat comparable to a heroin adict 1 month off the juice. Bottom line is, if you have an absurd amount of free time and are looking for a game to consume your life as a whole, make sure you download this game. If not, id steer clear.

reviewText:
This game is about clicking as fast as you can and managing upgrades to get better DPS.

Don't play it, it's very very addicting.

Just in case if you decided to give it a try still, I am leaving you advice which will save you hours (more like days and months) of your life.

How to get Dread Knight:
- Ascend after you got at least 8 Hero Souls (more is better)
- Get Vaagur, Ancient of Impatience

reviewText:
I would suggest this for when you're really bored, but...
It's really too much of a dull and unentertaining waste of time, which will add up, even if you play it only in short bursts or during breaks, to a larger amount of wasted time.

And we all know, Steam is counting your every minute spent on a game and can be quite merciless in displaying, to you and everybody, where you've been wasting your time.

My point is, that, if you start playing this game, it'll eventually make you wish you could get all the accumulated time back and instead spend it on a real game with an actual story or suspense curve, or fun.

So, if, in the first place, you can find the least bit of motivation to play anything less dull than this, I'd strongly suggest doing so!



If you still want to try this game... phew... go ahead.
Be warned again, though. It might seem fun at first. But once the game starts making you start over and over again for more hero souls, you will know what I was talking about.

Be warned also, that noone can get particularly good at it!
Your average DPS will always have been planned for, wherever you go, at least within min-max ranges. Because there's no build diversity in upgrading your heroes. Only one way to go.

Even if you intend to rule them all with your 'mighty autoclicker', you still won't get anywhere much faster or slower than the devs intend you to. Clicks per second are capped at 80.

Even if you could manage to progress somewhat faster, what's the point?! It's a single player game!

...With no end! I mean, you could put days, weeks, months into this but what for?!
Only to eventually notice that it has been offering too less for your time, all the time, and that almost any imaginable activity would have been more fun.

As I think of it, I found a good bottom line...

Remember the Men in Grey from the Momo novel? This game is them!

reviewText:
A seemingly endless cookie clicker game that can be quite addictive. With no story, the game is more about seeing how far you can get and seeing outrageously large numbers of damage and gold.

The game is pretty straightforward although there are a few ways to play it. Click the monsters to deal extra damage, collect their gold and spend the gold on your heroes which increase your overall DPS (the amount of damage dealt per second to the monster when you aren't clicking). Increasing your DPS will also increase your click damage as well. Being active in this way will allow you to get Rubies which would otherwise be bought through micro-transactions in the in-game shop. The other way is to rack up gold by idling, with the game closed you can earn gold when not playing.   Along the way as you level your heroes you can get some unique skills such as increasing the % of gold you earn per kill and ways to temporarily increase your DPS and click damage. Every 5 areas (zones) you'll fight a boss with tons of hit points. There is a catch though, you have to beat him within 30 seconds. This is the standard for testing the way you leveled your heroes and how much effort you put into leveling them.

Recommended for people who are bored, have old/slow PCs or Laptops or just straight up like addictive clicker games like these . Seeing as I'm temporarily (and reluctantly) using an old crappy computer for the rest of this week, I'll be playing this game for a while.

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Clicker Heroes is a clicking-indie-game developed by Playsaurus and released on steam in 2015, however the game was (and still is) available on web browsers July 2014.


-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: *Atratzu tactlessly copy pastes the description on steam into the story*  Okay, on a serious note, if there is a story it's that you're on an adventure and all these heroes are joining up to assist you. Where are you going? To get gold! That's about the whole thing, Scrooge McDuck.

Gameplay: in a word “clicking”. This is actually known as an “idle” or “afk” game. You don't give it very much attention once you start getting heroes, and you even get gold while you're not playing. However, you need to log in to purchase the next set of upgrades or beat the next set of levels/bosses.
When you first start out you need to click each time by yourself to take down the various monsters you're faced with. But soon you enlist the assistance of heroes to do all that clicking for you.
There are whole strategy guides out there on steam to help you maximize your efficiency while playing through the game, I personally just log in once before work, then when I get back home, then before bed. It's very easy to rack up hours on this game (since you can play it while you're doing other stuff) So it's very common to see people with many hundreds of hours.

Achievements: To be honest, I thought “free game”? “Play while I'm afk”? “Just requires clicking”? “+Steam Acheivements”? Sign me up! That should be an easy 100% achievements.
Noooooooooooooooo....
At this time I have about a fourth of the achievements in the game. There are 65 achievements in total, the first 10 achievements are pretty much “give me's”, the hardest achievements are “Beat Zone 3,400”, “Kill 100K bosses”, “Open 10,000 Treasure chests”, and many more. Generally after getting to Zone level 160, Clicker Heroes REALLY starts.
While the game is very easy to play, and rather addictive, it is not an “easy 100%”

Price: Clicker Heroes is completely free! So if you have free time to burn, this is your game. The only type of person I would warn about it is achievement hunters, because if you start this game your total game completion percentage will go down.
For everyone else.... Go ahead and give it a try! You'll at least get a good couple of hours of entertainment. And you might even get addicted.

Conclusion: In conclusion, this is a solid game, it's addicting, simple, fun, and free! It's definitely not a game that will hold your attention like Skyrim, GuildWars2, Bioshock, Left4Dead2, Counterstrike, or even other indie titles... but it doesn't try too! It embraces the definition of “afk game” and yet still makes it fun to play, in a strange almost mystical way.
I can easily recommend this to anyone with time to burn.

reviewText: A good casual game to sit and play for 10 to 15 minutes before or after work. Then after you become a little more powerful you get stuck at doing only up to level 160-170 for about 1 month. Before this game came to Steam and was only a flash game on the internet, with 100-150 souls you could reach level 180 with no problem and with 150+ souls you can do up to level 200+. Now, you play for a week or two, get to 100/200 souls and you can  reach level 130-160 with no problem. BUT after that comes the mega-uber-never-seen-before farming. I had 300 souls and I can barely reach level 170-180 level. Unless you give a lot of real money for this crappy game, then you will have to farm for the rest of your life. Oh... and at some point you will see that this game won't be so casual, you will sit for 10 minutes, but you will see that, that won't be enough at some point, the game forces you to waste up to 40-45 minutes of your time and probably even more as you progress. I do NOT think this game even deserves to be on Steam, but that's my opinion. In any case I do NOT recommend this game. It's a HUGE waste of your lifespan, believe me I lost somewhere around 30 hours(the 70 hours you see are because I've been AFK for over 30 hours) in this game. Believe me it isn't worth your time! I regret even starting to play this. I hope my review helped! :)

reviewText:
A fun little game. Ironically, despite being named Clicker Heroes, you will likely spend long periods not clicking at all once you are past the first few ascensions. Later, most players move to a hybrid style where the majority of a run is performed idle, and clicking is only used for the last five to ten minutes.

A few points that may put off some people. If you find any of these especially objectionable, this is likely not the game for you.

While usually classed as an 'idle' game, Clicker heroes requires more interaction than most games in that genre, especially during the first few ascensions.

It is also slow to start, usually requiring one to two days to get through your first ascension, and still requiring several hours to get through your next few. Once over that wall however, ascensions can drop down to thirty minutes or less.

Also, as is inherent with most games of this type, there is a lot of grinding, especially in the late game and, as previously mentioned, right at the beginning.

Finally, there is no actual end point at which you can say you have 'beat' the game. At the time of writing, the last defeatable boss occurs on floor 4720, but this may change in future updates, and does not limit the growth of your Ancients.

reviewText:
Clicker Heroes is a game with one button in mind... The left click button on your mouse!

All you do in this game is click. If you have played Adventure Capitalist you can tell they are very similar. Instead of investing in company's (which you do in adventure capitalist) you invest in Heroes! You are going on an adventure which catches the eyes of several powerful adventurers and heroes who aid you in your adventure. You will encounter such adventures such as Wizards, Mages, Ice apprentices and even Kings!

Rules for playing this game:
ⓍInvest in heroes and defeat monsters until you reach a high enough level
ⓍWait a day
Ⓧ1000000000000000 QUINTILLION TRILLION QUINZILLION Coins
ⓍDo 2 Push Ups and a Squat
ⓍRepeat

reviewText: I always give games a fair chance. And I played this one for now 17.5 hours, got to level 113 I think and then stopped because there is absolutely no point in it and it really annoyed me that it just got slower and slower to the point where I would pretty much have to restart it to do anything to continue. This mechanic is totally not fun where the game producers just made a game with minimal effort and then decided they are too lazy to add anything more to it so they just made it harder and you have to restart it. There is no real achievement in this game, no story, no point whatsoever, you just click and click, buy heroes which do nothing and don't ever appear on screen, you just get more numbers and more numerical upgrades. And the damage increase is something like this: At the beginning you do 1 damage. Then at some point you do 1M damage then 1b and 1t and so on and the monsters all look the same. And you can't even advance the game by playing it. Quickly after you get the game you realize you just have to quit and let it auto-calculate the money you'd be making, then come back, put some more useless upgrades and repeat, And then, it gets to a point where it is realistically impossible to do anything other than restart it for a bit of extra damage. Yes, actually RESTARTING it meaning you will go through the EXACT same many levels as before and throw away the hundreds of upgrades you got for your heroes and lose your progress and then having to beat the same monsters that give you little gold and look the same to buy the same exact heroes that do nothing with the same exact upgrades and just let it 'play itself again' so you can get in it and play it for a few minutes the next morning or something. This game is utterly STUPID in this sense and I really can't believe that the gaming industry which has set new standards for large stories, large worlds. complex gameplay, art and awesome feeling can have all these standards completely ignored and have people produce a game in which you just click, buy upgrades that don't do anything, you just see different numbers on screen, heroes which don't even appear on screen and then there is absolutely no continuity-you have to restart and go through the same exact boring stuff which was not complex in any way to begin with. What is the point of restarting, losing my hero who got to level 650 so that I have him from level 1 to upgrade him again in absolutely the exact same way and get the same exact 'skills' (there are no choices here, just a 'damage' boosting level-up) in a way which brings me no satisfaction? This game is absolutely worthless. And I am glad I didn't do any microtransactions because they are just disgusting in this game. So you have the option to pay real life money that you work for just so that you can avoid the stupid mechanic of having to restart the game all over again or having to let it 'play in the background' so you can do anything with it. I am glad I didn't pay anything in the microtransactions because I would have felt cheated and I already feel cheated because the steam achievement system has already mixed my rate of game achievements with the one in this game and got it down because the achivements in this game are absolutely ridiculous-like an achievement to restart the world 160 times or something. So I played the game for a week, then had to throw everything away to restart it once and they have an achievement to do it 160 times around...absolutely pointless. I love games very much and praise them for their entertainment and education value but this game is just absolutely pointless. Thumbs down. Don't play it. You will get a false sense of achievement for a little while then realize this game is a very brutal and insulting scam where you just stop progressing and have to pay for it. So I should pay 100$ to get rubbies just so that I don't have to game 'play itself' and have to do useless levelling and restarting. What is the point and satisfaction in that? Absolutely none, I spend money on games to get satisfaction from them, not to avoid getting annoyed as much as possible by them. I now realize this game is absolutely abusive in that way :). I am glad I didn't put money in it just for the achievements because the I would have looked at them and remembered how I sent a lot of money to get cheated by a game...this game is absolutely a hoax and shoudn't be on steam. I hope games like this and adventure capitalism will soon not be allowed on here anymore because they are insultingly trying to rob you while pretending to be a game.  Better than pay 100$ for rubbies which  will just let you play-I don't know, maybe an extra 20 minutes continuously without having to let it play in the background because it as all you do, better buy some awesome and complex RPG like Skyrim, Witcher, Dragon Age or anything really which will keep you playing for hundreds of hours and give you really fond memories, art and feeling. Or you can buy a real life collector's edition of a real and really awesome game with that money :). The only feeling I have after playing this game is that it tried to cheat me to pay for something I didn't want or would bring me any happiness and I am relieved I uninstalled it. I hope 'games' like this stop appearing on here because they are not games, they are a hoax in disguise, and I really liked steam a lot before, now I am unhappy with it that it lets games like this in here to just try to rip its customers of for a little more money while causing great unhappiness afterwards. This is really bad marketing, Steam is encouraging this with the achievement thing so you have a false sense of achievement and in the end if you pay for it you will probably feel very unhappy and cheated because you got nothing for your money, you just got abused...

reviewText:
Alright, remember cookieclicker ? Yeah ? If you do and you got addicted to it then this game is worse - in terms of getting addicting.

This is simply an addicting clicking game where you ... click ... on a monster. You might think it's boring but some other features take care of that. You can hire heroes and buy upgrades for those heroes and - no i'm not finished yet - you have skills that you can use ! (Obviously with some cooldown) Most of the heroes does dps (damage per second) and the more you have .. the easier it gets for your finger. It does damage automaticly after all.

Furthermore, this is not a pay-to-win game. It does have a shop with their own currency (rubies) but I don't think you need it. It might be a way to support the developers tho, maybe .. i guess. The game drops sometimes a ruby here and there (yes, rarely). There are also hero souls, but for now I don't know what it's used for.

Some tips:
If you're playing on a laptop - use your mousepad and 2 fingers = double clicking speed !
For people that only have a mouse and one finger to touch that mousebutton... don't click too hard or you'll need another mouse.
You can easily farm:
When you close the game and later open it again then don't be shocked when you suddenly have much gold.
You can do other tasks when the game is running, whenever you have x dps (damage per second) it does it automatically for you.You can save a game and import it later (on another pc or so)
Also, there will be a difference at making love with your girlfriend - it will improve sooner or later ;) (like i will do ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°) )

And how to close this game ? (No, really .. there's no exit to desktop" or any kind)
Have fun clicking all !!  ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)  ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)"

reviewText:
Name says all. With your clicks you deal damage to the monsters and every killed one drops money. You use this money to level up your heroes; monsters of higher zones have more health but also drop more money. There are 10 enemies per zone and every 5th zone is a boss. Some of these bosses drop Hero Souls (HS). They raise your damage (10% per HS) and you can buy or level up Ancients (there is one for everything: more money, more damage, more HS, more, more, more). Once you can’t go any higher you ascent (restart) and go again, so every run should go deeper and faster.

They just added clans, where you fight with 9 other players against bosses (3 x 30 seconds every day). The reward are some additional HS for your main game.

And yes it’s totally free. You can buy Rubies (the currency of the game). But consider it more as a donation, because you’ll get them for free while playing.

The graphics are OK and a million times better than this creepy Steam summer game.

Sounds easy: You’ll click at least one million times till your right hand hurts; then (with the right ancients) you don’t even need to do this anymore. You just level up your heroes. Day by day, week by week.

Is it fun: WTF, didn’t you read above?! I just told you this game is boring and repetitive. I’m sitting here every day and level up my heroes. That’s all: level up heroes! Live, die, repeat; live, die, repeat… Yeah, most fun ever!

But why are so many play this (you have over  100 hours): Because no one warned us. We made the big mistake and clicked install and play. So better leave this site and never come back, or your life will be over (at least for the next year). It’s like a drug, once started you just can’t stop! TV: boring, just a quick run. Sleep: just a quick run. What game next: OK, just a quick run. Now we are only clicker zombies.

And this game…

Wait...why are you still reading this? I already told you to leave. Leave this site and never come back, there’s some hope left for you. The zombie army is growing. Leave now. NOW!!!!!!

reviewText: This definitely isn't a recreation of Line's Gold Rush. This is 100% original. Garbage games like the Fallout series and the Grand Theft Auto series could really learn something from this true masterpiece.

reviewText:
Idle game it ain't.

The mechanics requires you to be paying attention to actually progress. You can't leave it running and play something else unless you want to alt-tab back to it every minute or two. But it has the timespan of an idle game - i.e. months/years. You'll either get annoyed and quit after a few weeks having achieved diddly squat, or spend every waking minute working towards just one more ascension" and neglecting better games or more useful things to do with your time.

Do your sanity a favour and don't get hooked."

reviewText:
For everyone complaining about the microtransactions, this game has been through many different experiences... even though I only have 22 hours, I have played this game for months before it was on Steam. You can stop for however long you want and come back to money. I started at version 3, played through until 13, stopped and came back for 14-17b while the game did not have microtransactions. The style of playing the game changes depending on who you are but it never required rubies or autoclickers. The original style before ancients that disappeared due to a change at version 11 was using (or abusing according to the developers) the damage multiplier from the ritual. That was nerfed and was replaced with ancients which required the new souls. These souls were given based on the progress you had made up that point, giving everyone free amounts of souls (30 hero souls for level 120). The new style was for me was taking advantage of theclick combo or idle multipliers.. Both adding new styles of gameplay. I came back to play again to finish getting the newly added achievements along with the steam counterparts to them.

Rubies are not necessary.
Autoclickers are not necessary.

Ancients provide a way to progress.
Things are taking too long? Ascend and get upgrades.

(Updated with more precise version numbers)

reviewText: A brilliant meta-satire on skinner box games, but not really much of a game itself. Clicker heroes is a game where you grind, so that you can grind faster, so that you can grind, so that you can grind faster, etc. in a never ending cycle of grinding. But what is the actual grind? Nothing. You just sit and watch as numbers get bigger. You have no real choices to make. You earn gold to spend on upgrades to earn more gold so that you can spend on upgrades to earn more gold and there are no wrong choices, only slightly inefficient ones. You can do some clicking as well but 99% of the time you don't need to. If you ever played a game like Diablo, any kind of loot game or RPG where you grinded to level up, you get the exact same experience, but here you don't have to do anything at all. It's brilliant how they distilled the essence of an entire genre into its bare components and showed how pointless and stupid Diablo-esque or any game with grinding in it is. Even though I didn't recommend it, because the game is shallow and pointless, you may as well at least try it, since it is free, and think of this brilliant game when you play other skinner box type games.

At first i tough it will be good to get high gilded Heroes since they were strong but even getting Frostleaf x2 gilded i felt lucky at a moment until i understood that he can't bring me any higher, Dread knight became my dream i tough i could own these monsters with he's help but the payment for he's help was unreachable.

reviewText:
Funny clicker game that is more addicting than some other expensive games, as known as clicker warfare, this game is actually kind of funny and cool, but there should be more into it.

- There are lots of achievements in game, but only a few are on Steam, all of them should be added to Steam so it would make the game funnier and more addicting because everyone wants them.
- Only 1 song on the soundtrack, add some more songs, indie songs, anything that matches with this game.

I couldn't find any more cons, now these are some of the pros.

- It's addicting as hell, and the best part is, it's actually fun.
- Always something to do, there is never an end.
- The game is easy to learn and easy to master.
- Everything is well designed.
- The difficulty to get from an hero to another is absurd when we reach Frostleaf, that makes it challenging.

I dont know any more pros, the game itself is just funny and addicting, and it's free, try it out!

reviewText:
Can a game where all you do is click your mouse be good?

Yes, it can.  Almost every game I've played, even some of the games I pre ordered, I didn't play long my first session.  Usually takes me a few plays to get into the game enough to stay playing for hours at a time.  I've played one session on this game so far, 4.3 hours worth.

This game can be addicting.  You play a while, constantly trying to get a little more gold to level up your guys then tell yourself Self
date:
I think I'm going to take a break from this and play something else".  Then 4 hours later you're finally able to pull yourself from the game.

Review:
ProsThe game is SIMPLE
recommended: almost as simple as they get It's actually pretty entertaining\nRuns very smooth
hoursPlayed: no frame rate drops or anything and in the 4 hours I played
voteText: 0 bugs that I noticed\nIts FREE to play.  Of course has an item shop (How do you expect these guys to make money otherwise?)\nYou don't need to buy anything.  I made it to lvl 52 in the 4 hours I played
helpfulPercent: sometimes staying in a level for a long time until I got each one to die within 1 second with just my warriors dps and haven't needed any items from the shop. I'm sure later down the levels they may come in handy though\nThe Upgrade system is nice.  You buy warriors to help you kill the monsters.  They add some DPS to the fight so you don't have to click as much to kill.  You can upgrade them and unlock new skills/perks which make a huge difference.\nOnce you build enough dps
votesHelpful: you can take a break from the game and it will still make gold for you.  My daughter had a major leg surgery last week and we have to help her get around the house.. I let the game set while I helped her and came back to having about 500b gold.  This also helps you when your wrist gets tired
votesTotal: just stop clicking and let the game take over.\nCons\nHonestly
votesFunny: I don't really have much to say for the negatives of the game
commentsCount: but I'll give it a shot.\nIt's simple.  This is a good thing and a bad.  If you want something to kill some time that's not difficult
column16: this game is for you.  BUT if you're wanting a little more than just clicking your mouse and buying some upgrades
column17: this probably isn't for you.\nYou can feel a little strain in your wrist area if you click too much\nNeeds an EXIT button.. As far as I could tell there wasn't one... I had to ALT F4 to get out.  Not a big deal
column18: but wouldn't hurt to have one for those out there that don't know how to exit a program using alt f4.. And yes
column20: there are some still out there.\nI'll post a short video later of what I got done in 4 hours."

reviewText:
(Update added at the end)
This is one of the worst games I have ever played! And the developer is an evil genius!

It's just about clicking on a monster that is just there, kill it, get money, get upgrades to kill more monsters faster and get more money to get more upgrades, rinse and repeat, THAT'S IT! Oh and you can leave at any moment and the game will continue killing and gainning money for you.


IT'S SUPER STUPID AND YET SUPER ADDICTIVE!! LIKE A DRUG!! I HATE THIS GAME AND I LIKE IT!!!....

... did I mention you have to restart many times the whole thing? Yes, you have to if you want to advance quickly, play all the levels you have been through, and then you realize DA F^CK!! It took me one day to reach this level and now that I restarted it takes me a couple of hours!"

DON'T PLAY THIS GAME! You have been warned...



Update: After 1225 hours I got the last achivement
date: I played mostly 15% of that time actively (and while reading news

reviewText:
8.5/10 - What a great waste of time!

No idea what is so extremly fascinating about growing numbers, but DAMN its addicting. So far i'm 600 hours into this game and only reached the far mid-game.
600 hours from a free2play game? - Worth it!! Though it's still an idle game and of course thats not active gametime, but still.

The game itself is suprisingly deep and comes up with many different ideas to bring lots of variety into the gameplay. Admitting, it's not perfect, but definitely one of the top idle games out there!

Love idle games? Looking for a game you can play brain-afk while watching a movie? - You just found the perfect title!

reviewText: You're at Home Depot and you have to take a dump, but it's in the back of your mind. You don't really need to go right now. You continue shopping and eventually you need some help. So you ask the guy named Steve to help you find the right lightbulb for your wife's lamp (she is never happy with the choices you make, but how can you screw up a lightbulb?). So you and Steve go and look and you find the perfect one on the display model. You look down but you can't find one in its box, so you ask Steve if he can find one. He looks again, but he can't find it where you just looked (I guess he doesn't trust you). So Steve goes to the back and looks for a lightbulb. All of a sudden, that ♥♥♥♥ starting coming back to you. One minute you are fine, the next it starts turtling out. You're afraid of public restrooms (freaking high school, right?) so you run to your car, forgetting the lightbulb and Steve, and drive back home. That drive home is painful. Your stomach is growling and your ♥♥♥ feels likes you're in prison. You make it in, run past your wife who is screaming at you for not getting a lightbulb, and run to the bathroom and quickly shut and lock the door (you wouldn't want your wife barging in). You sit on the toilet seat with your pants down and begin the slow ascension to ecstasy.\n\nThat moment when the first poop falls is how this game feels.

reviewText:
I usually dont write reviews for game, but for this one i must.

I first started to play the game and thought it was pretty awesome.
Not too grindy at the start, and the start is actual pure fun.
After you get into the late game, its mostly about the gameplay mechanics that release endorphins (the chemical that makes you happy)

This game is simple, it takes the cookie clicker addictive mechanic, and puts it into a fantasy RPG setting.

I highly recommend trying out this game, im really enjoying doing it in my downtime.

reviewText:
Clicker Heroes is free to play. Strange thing about this game is it still plays even when you're not there.

Cute and fuzzy enemies drop onto a platform which is meant to represent an area or location. You click on them to attack and after killing them you get some money. Money is spent on buying team members who contribute to your damage per second. You can also use the money to upgrade your characters simply by leveling them up and increasing their DPS, Eventually there is a chance you might be able to add on some perks of theres and even cast some spells which create some buffs but only for a short time. You can complete an area by killing 10 enemies then you move on to the next area, the monsters might take a lil bit longer to kill but if your DPS is stupid high you wont even have a chance to click to move on. There's boss battles every now and then but its just a longer life  bar and they can withstand damage better than the lesser minions. Then you just move on. and it repeats. over and over and over again...
Just when you think you've got the top upgrade, There's another character to unlock and it seems to be no max level on anything.

They don't fight back so you can't really lose. In fact if you dont attempt to attack, enemies will just stand there waiting to die. I think the game should be renamed and called 'Clicker Fodder' because I dont see what can be so heroic about killing suicidal crane game creatures. However it IS free and I've put some time into it just so see where it would go but unfortunately I'd probably give it the thumbs down. Its fun to watch and see how fast you can kill a critter within seconds after you've invested in the upgrades. You can even entertain yourself by trying to click as fast as you can. But I just felt like the gimmick wears out pretty quickly.
voteText: 17 of 31 people (55%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
This game is super fun. It really does hold up to its standard of time-wasting which I'm being positive about.

Although people can use macros to speed up the process without actually playing the game, it seems boring that way. It would seem better to wear out your finger and get use out of the game than to let the game play on and on without you doing anything productive.

Again, this game holds up to its positive time-wasting standard, I hope this game can grow to the fullest and become a good game in the steam community.

reviewText:
This game is bad... but addicting at the same time, well, It's free so who I am to complain.

1.Start the game.
2.Break your mouse.
3.Buy a new mouse.
4.Clicking on your left mouse button like crazy.
5.Let your heroes kill the monsters while you're away (or doing something else).

The game was kind of fun the first minutes but after that, you'll just go afk and let your heroes does the rest for you (once they're high level enough to kill monsters).

It's not a bad game but It's not a game you would be playing without doing something else like watching the TV, playing another game, kissing your wife or husband.
If you do play this game and only this game all day then you are crazy.

I've seen a lot on the forums about an app called autoclicker, If you're just to use an app to finish the game, why even bother playing it at the first place? That doesn't makes sense.

It can be fun while having something else to do at the same time but other than that, It's more of a waste of time that will destroy your life if you always play it because it can get very long.

Also, It's almost like Call of Duty but even better, all you have to do is click" "click" "click" "click" "dead" "click" "click" "click" "dead" but the thing is that you do not die! Awesome
date: no? Well okay maybe not but it is still better than Call of Duty Modern Warfare 3
recommended: Black ops and every Call of Duty games after those.\n\n6/10 still better than every Call Of Duty after Call of Duty: Black ops (including Call of Duty: Black ops)."

reviewText:
Here we go again...

Not my favourite of the genre, but I was having an anxiety freakout last night and it was the exact sort of soothing repetitive background task I needed.  (I don't really actively play, so much as keep an eye on it and poke things sometimes.  YMMV.)

All in all a solid endless progression game, though some of the jokes are cruel rather than funny; I'd recommend not reading the flavour text.  Destructively brain-eating if you let it have full sway, but as a mental health tool it's super useful.

reviewText:
A fun new take on clicking based games such as cookie clicker or adventure capitalist.  If you like any of those clicking, idling or farming games, then you'll probably like this as well.  Its interesting to keep up to date with your heroes as far as upgrades and levels.  There is just something about these games that makes them so entertaining.  Now the one thing I've noticed is there is micro-transactions and there are people who instantly hate a game because of that, however, consider the following:

-The game is free to play.
-After the fact above, paying for anything else is the only financial support this game will get.
-I don't see this as a traditional pay2win complaint since you don't have to worry about other players doing this unlike in other games with this feature.
-You don't ever really need to buy any of the abilities, they can earned in-game by grinding the crap out of it...like you should anyway.

Other than that, it is repetitive, but all clicker games are in their own way.  I have no real complaints.  Its fun and interesting, auto clicker software works on it, and it can run in the background to make grinding less painful.  With no cost to you, check it out and maybe for once buy some rubies to support this great greenlite game.

reviewText:
An endless grind, I wouldn't call it a perfect game, but it sure as hell gives you a reason to keep playing, and you could even let it run in the background to grind for you.

It's addicting and fun at first, but it does become very repetitive, there are so many ways to upgraade your heroes and increase your damage output, having acsension is like new game + in other games.

Don't feel ashamed if you end up using an autoclicker, I don't think the designers expected the hardcore grinders to sit here clicking all day, as you get to the later stages it gets tiring, I almost feel like autoclicker is needed at a certain point, otherwise you'll be spending way more time trying to get enough dps for bosses.

8/10 I recommend you try this, and I hope they continue to add more features, for a f2p game I am impressed, but I love grind heavy games.

reviewText:
Clicker Heroes in a Nutshell
Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click... Click...

In short  clicker heroes is a very addictive clicking prison game which has only one aim to consume your soul to level up your heroes and move through the physical representation of hell game. As you get your soul consumed further in the game you will find souls of players heroes allowing you to progress. Recruit powerful adventurers and mythological beasts who help you progress in your unescapable oblivion epic quest.
Run while you still can Have Fun!
9/10
